content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in years,” and the heading for row 2 is “R of t, in bears per year.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0; R of t is 150. Column 2. t is 4; R of t is 156. Column 3. t is 9; R of t is 159. Column 4. t is 12; R of t is 161." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid none" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(years)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>9</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>R</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(bears per year)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>150</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>156</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>159</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>161</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

The rate at which the number of bears in a region is changing is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in bears per year and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in years. Selected values of <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table.

(a) Approximate <math alttext="R prime of 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="4 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer, and indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in years,” and the heading for row 2 is “R of t, in bears per year.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0; R of t is 150. Column 2. t is 4; R of t is 156. Column 3. t is 9; R of t is 159. Column 4. t is 12; R of t is 161." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid none" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(years)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>9</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>R</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(bears per year)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>150</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>156</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>159</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>161</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

The rate at which the number of bears in a region is changing is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in bears per year and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in years. Selected values of <math alttext="R of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table.

(a) Approximate <math alttext="R prime of 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="4 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer, and indicate units of measure.

(b) Interpret the meaning of <math alttext="one twelfth times, the integral from 0 to 12, of, R of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem. Use a left Riemann sum with the three subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate the value of <math alttext="one twelfth times, the integral from 0 to 12, of, R of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) The rate at which the number of bears in the region is changing can also be modeled by the function <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> defined by <math alttext="P of t equals, 150 times e raised to the 0.02 times the square root of t, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>150</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0.02</mn><msqrt><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="P of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in bears per year and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is measured in years. There are <math alttext="300" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> bears in the region at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use this model to find the number of bears in the region at time <math alttext="t equals 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the setup for your calculations, and give your answer to the nearest whole number of bears.

(d) Using the model defined in part (c), find the time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, at which the number of bears in the region is a maximum. Justify your answer.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
